snippet: Despite improved living standards, the poor have fallen further behind the middle class and the affluent in both consumption and income, and crucial services remain unattainable.
abstract: Economists say while electronics and other factory-made goods are now within reach of poor Americans, crucial services like education, health care and child care remain unattainable; hold that federal programs and falling prices account for much of the change in poor families' consumption over the past generation; starkly different views on poverty and inequality emerge again as Senate Republicans filibuster proposal to raise national minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: Despite improved living standards, the poor have fallen further behind the middle class and the affluent in both consumption and income, and crucial services remain unattainable.

headline.main: Changed Life of the Poor: Better Off, but Far Behind
headline.print_headline: Changed Life of the Poor: Better Off, but Far Behind
